ADU1.text: "Pico focuses on Anaxagoras because he considers him as a precursor of the later Neoplatonic concept all things exist in all things in their own mode

ADU2.text: "Anaxagoras holds the view that objects are temporary mixtures of ingredients

ADU3.text: "Anaxagoras shares with Parmenides the principle that what-is is without start or stop."

ADU4.text: "The Intellect sets the mixture into rotary motion: everything is mixture and separation of ingredients."

ADU5.text: "Pico correlates the philosophy of Anaxagoras with the conclusion that cum in ipsa ita sunt omnia

ADU6.text: "The later Neoplatonic concept Πάντα ἐν πᾶσιν

ADU8.text: "Pico argues that there is a Demiurge of the Intellect

ADU9.text: "Anaxagoras is adamant: the Intellect is separate

ADU10.text: "Aristotle notes that Anaxagoras failed to explain how Intellect comes to think."

ADU11.text: "Pico's vocabulary indicates that he is relying on a Neoplatonic commentary on Aristotle's Physics."

ADU12.text: "Pico could also have drawn from John Philoponus's In Aristotelis physicorum libros commentaria."

ADU13.text: "Simplicius and Philoponus holds that the Intellect distinguishes the homoiomereias

ADU14.text: "Pico supports that the opifex intellectus distinguishes the omiomeria."

ADU15.text: "Anaxagoras never refers to a possible creator of the Intellect."

ADU16.text: "Plotinus associates the Demiurge with Intellect and not with the One."

ADU17.text: "Pico's argument no longer opposes the philosophy of Anaxagoras."

ADU18.text: "Anaxagoras does not call the Intellect Demiurge nor does he conflate Intellect with God or divine principle."

ADU19.text: "Pico's unambiguous affirmation that the Intellect creates the universe supports the translation of Pico's phrase opifex intellectus as Demiurge-Intellect."

ADU20.text: "Anaxagoras's principle is supportive to Pico's metaphysics."

ADU21.text: "Anaxagoras's philosophy permits Pico to establish his doctrine that all things share a portion of God within them

ADU22.text: "Anaxagoras's metaphysical principle is supportive to Pico's method of allegorical interpretation."

ADU23.text: "Anaxagoras assumes that all things are found together in the original mixture and everything is in everything at all times."

ADU24.text: "Pico refutes instead Anaxagoras's argument and insists that the Intellect is greatly mixed."

ADU25.text: "Pico expresses a similar view in the Commento

ADU26.text: "Plotinus's interpretation of Anaxagoras's philosophy concerning the principle everything in everything is convenient for Pico's view that the greatest mixture coincides with the greatest simplicity in the intellectual nature."
